titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Fritz Leiber Papers
titlestmt.author: Katherine Fox

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was encoded in EAD by Archon 3.21 from an SQL database source on October 17th, 2016.
profiledesc.langusage: The collection description/finding aid is written in English

titlepage.titleproper: Guide to the Fritz Leiber Papers 1930/1996

did.head: Overview of the Collection

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries

did.abstract: The Fritz Leiber Papers contains correspondence, notes, manuscripts, typescripts, publications and tearsheets, diaries and biographical materials, financial, legal and medical records, photographs, illustrations, convention materials, and miscellaneous materials. Additional oversize art/illustration materials and ephemera such as weaponry, sculpture, and awards are housed separately. The materials date from the 1930s to the 1980s. They are housed in 60 manuscripts boxes, 5 storage boxes, and 3 oversized boxes.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information:
bioghist.p: Fritz Reuter Leiber, Jr. was born in Chicago on December 24, 1910 to Shakespearean actors Fritz Leiber, Sr. and Virginia Bronson Leiber. He graduated from the University of Chicago in 1932 with a degree in psychology and physiology, and, in 1936, married Jonquil Stephens, a British poet with similar interests in the supernatural. They had one son, Justin Leiber, in 1938. Several years after Jonquil's death in 1969, he married Margo Skinner. His employment throughout the years included editorial positions and teaching drama, but Fritz Leiber primarily supported himself with his writing.

Producing stories in the genres of fantasy, science, horror, and supernatural fiction from the mid 1930s until his death in 1992, Fritz Leiber won several prominent fantasy and science fiction awards such as the Hugo, the Nebula, and the World Fantasy Association Awards. Although he wrote numerous stories in variety of styles, Leiber is perhaps best known for the heroic Fafhrd and the Gray Mouser characters he created with his college friend, Harry Otto Fischer (1910-1986), and which he continued to embellish through a series of short stories and novels throughout his long writing career and correspondence with Fischer.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information:
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated to the University of Houston by Fritz Leiber and Justin Leiber, his son, between 1984 and 1997. Additional correspondence between Fritz Leiber and Franklin C. MacKnight was donated by Dr. MacKnight.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use:
userestrict.p: Special Collections owns the physical items in our collections, but copyright normally belongs to the creator of the materials or their heirs. The researcher has full responsibility for determining copyright status, locating copyright holders, and abiding by current copyright laws when publishing or displaying copies of Special Collections material in print or electronic form. For more information, consult the appropriate librarian.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: Fritz Leiber Papers, Courtesy of Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials:
relatedmaterial.p: Fritz Leiber Science Fiction & Fantasy Convention Flyers & Programs digital collection

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Fritz Leiber Papers contains correspondence, notes, manuscripts, typescripts, publications and tearsheets, diaries and biographical materials, financial, legal and medical records, photographs, illustrations, convention materials, and miscellaneous materials. Additional oversize art/illustration materials and ephemera such as weaponry, sculpture, and awards are housed separately. The materials date from the 1930s to the 1980s. They are housed in 60 manuscripts boxes, 5 storage boxes, and 3 oversized boxes.

The collection was compiled from 41 boxes of previously unprocessed Fritz Leiber materials, 23 boxes of Fritz Leiber papers which were processed in 1991-1992, and several boxes of letters which were donated by Franklin C. MacKnight from 1984-1991. Original provenance was lost through preliminary processing, so the order imposed on the Fritz Leiber Papers is artificial and reflects the major categories discovered during final processing. For more information, please refer to the series descriptions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes correspondence between Fritz Leiber and friends, editors, and fans with the largest series being between Fritz Leiber and his friends Harry Otto Fischer and F.C. MacKnight. Correspondence is filed alphabetically by the last name of the correspondent, then by written or inferred date. Partially dated or undated materials are filed behind all dated materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains handwritten or typed notes for various Fritz Leiber stories. Notes are filed alphabetically by the title of the work. Unidentifiable notes are filed last.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fritz Leiber's manuscripts and typescripts filed alphabetically by title. Works include but are not limited to short stories, novels, fantasy magazine columns, scientific articles, astronomical/astrological, and poetry.

scopecontent.p: Fritz Leiber's reviews of other authors' science fiction, fantasy, or literary works. This series is organized alphabetically by story title, if only the title is known, and by author, then title when the author is known.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fritz Leiber's spiral bound notebooks from 1972-1989, as well as several miscellaneous notebooks and sporadically filled out, undated diaries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interviews, bibliographies, biographical and autobiographical materials, genealogical items, clippings, about Fritz Leiber. Includes Fritz Leiber's obituary notices.

did.unittitle: Biographical materials - Quotes about Fritz Leiber

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tax returns, bills, canceled checks, check stubs, banking statements, and miscellaneous receipts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Royalty statements from various publishers for sales of Fritz Leiber works around the world. Arranged alphabetically by name of publishing house.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Literary contracts and agreements filed alphabetically, copyright applications filed chronologically, estate papers for Fritz Leiber's first wife, aunt, and cousin as well as rental agreements and miscellaneous legal documents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fritz Leiber's addiction rehabilitation documentation, notes on his eye surgery, as well as death certificate, funeral/cremation/memorial services arrangements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs and negatives of Fritz Leiber, his family, friends (identified and unidentified), and personal and professional activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Artwork, photography, and illustrations of science fiction or fantasy topics. Very few of these pieces can be definitively linked to specific Fritz Leiber stories.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Flyers, programs, schedules, etc. of various science fiction and fantasy conventions Fritz Leiber either attended or was invited to attend. Filed alphabetically by the name of the convention.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials in many different formats including publications with no Leiber material in them, awards/certificates, publishers' catalogs, clippings on various topics and items, and items relating to chess, theater, travel, and the University of Chicago. Publications are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscripts of other authors, including Harlan Ellison, Harry O. Fischer, Jonquil Stephens Leiber, Justin Leiber, Arlynn Patrick [Leiber], James Tucker, and Gene Wolfe.
